Reviews.Title: “Very pleasant and affordable stay”
Reviews.Author: Vlajek
Reviews.Content: Stayed for five nights in a single room. Best location for museum enthusiasts: within a short walk to Prado/Reina Sofia/Thyssen. The room was small and basic, had a/c, private bathtube and toilet. The window looked into a small patio. Everything was perfectly cleaned on a daily basis. The staff were helpful and very friendly. The hostel itself is on the 2nd floor of a typical restored 19th century building with atmospheric elevator and old wooden doors. The neighbourhood is quiet and nice.

Reviews.Title: “An art lover's delight”
Reviews.Author: Amyrlin
Reviews.Content: This is a little gem of pension. Within walking distance - a gentle stroll really - of two metro stations, the Puerta de Sol, the Plaza Mayor and the centre of Madrid. The three great art museums - the Prado, Thyssen-Bornimiza and Reina de Sofia are within spitting distance. The airport bus stop is an easy 300 metres away and the delightful cafe/bar next door also provides wifi access and a fantastic breakfast. My room was small but tidy with clean towels provided daily. It could however have been cleaner. The bed head had not been dusted for some time, and I did find the cigarette smoke that drifted up into the room when I opened the windows into the central well of the apartment building, in preference to using the air-conditioning, disconcerting. For people who don't mind dust or cigarette smoke this will be an ideal pension. It does offer excellent value for money. I will certainly consider staying there again and will recommend it to friends.

Reviews.Title: “Outstanding location, spotless and authentic”
Reviews.Author: IanM327
Reviews.Content: I first discovered this gem in the Rough Guide, whilst living in Madrid and needing a place for friends and family to stay when they came to visit. This was 12 years ago and although it's not as cheap as it was, it's everything you'd want, if you want the real Madrid. Going east it's 5 minutes walk to the Prado and 10 to the Retiro: west it's 5 minutes to Pl Sta Ana and 10 to Sol. Turn left outside the front door (west) and at the end of the street (50 metres), turn right and you're in the heart of a fantastic area for tapas. In the other direction, Plaza Santa Ana is wonderful and you can spend hours watching the Madrilenos go by, drinking natural brown beer (tostada) at the Naturbier bar. All the hostal's facilities are adequately and fully described in other reviews. What may be helpful is that, although no breakfast is provided, the bar Casa Merani is right at the foot of the stairs and owned by the wonderful Alfredo. He's really friendly and helpful and full of laughter. I don't think that either Alfredonor the patrons of Dulcinea speak much Engliish, but this needn't put you off, as there's always a way, and you want to experience Madrid, don't you? You can get to the Hostal in about 20 minutes from Barajas. Catch the airport bus from outside the terminal building (5 Euros) and look for the 'stops' on the neon sign. You can get off at Cibeles or, if you're brave, wait until you leave Cibeles and ask the driver to drop you at the next stop. This bus doesn't normally stop at these stops but it works for us, and the next stop is right at the end of Calle Cervantes. All in all I didn't want to recommend Dulcinea because each year it gets harder to book, but the owners really deserve the praise!

Reviews.Title: “Great location! Madrid experience!”
Reviews.Author: Lia N
Reviews.Content: This is such a cute little hostel and the price is great for the location! Ideal for budget travel! Close to metro and bus stops and all the main attractions. It's almost across the Prado museum! Once we figured out the narrow little streets surrounding it (which was a lot easier than anticipated), it was easy to walk to all the main sights and even to the Puerto del Sol and the palace! This is a great place to stay if you want to have the ideal Madrid experience. It's in range of unique small shops and bars with a Starbucks just 100ft away. The owner was friendly but did not speak any english at all. He just smiled at us. The rooms were clean and we had a small terrace looking out over the narrow street below. Beds were nice. One thing to know is that the bathroom is small, very small and a grown man of 1.7m might have trouble moving around in it... Otherwise, I would greatly reccomend staying here!

Reviews.Title: “Good location, nice room.”
Reviews.Author: Lariscampos
Reviews.Content: Close to all the museums and to the center of Madrid, the hostal is really well located. The room size was ok, it was clean and the wifi worked ok. Fair price for a simple, but good hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Inexpensive, short walk to museums & restaurants”
Reviews.Author: palmtree7270
Reviews.Content: Our hosts were very polite despite our lack of spanish-speaking skills. Wi fi was difficult to establish at first, but on our third day, we were able to access it easily from our room. Our hosts offered us an inside room, but recommended a balcony room, which was nice & sunny. It was nice to have fresh air with the double doors opened. The balcony itself is small, no room to sit on, but fine for our purposes. Our balcony overlooked a safe side street. Street noise is as expected in a city. Beds are comfortable, no problems sleeping. Room & bathroom were cleaned daily. Bring a round-shaped 220 converter so you can recharge your electronics. Packets of shampoo & small round soaps are provided. Small room safe fits wallets & cameras, not iPads or laptops. The room also had a key-locked built-in wardrobe for our luggage. There is a flatscreen wall-mounted TV with remote. You can walk around the corner to a VIPS or Starbucks, both of which offer free wi fi for 45 mins with purchase. Plenty of relatively reasonably-priced restaurants were also very nearby in any direction we walked from the hotel. Expect to pay about 50 euros for a decent dinner for two, including a pitcher of sangria. We walked a little further to Plaza de Santa Ana, where we found Tablao VillaRosa, a restaurant with live flamenco dancing. It made for a fun evening. We're not night-clubbers, but plenty of clubs were to be found in the general area. And oh yes, it's very convenient to the 3 most popular museums, the Prado, the Thyssen, & the Reina Sofia. Reina Sofia is one of the few attractions open on Mondays. This was the most affordable hotel with excellent reviews that we could find near the museums, using TripAdvisor & I think booking.com.

Reviews.Title: “Recommended”
Reviews.Author: Marisa G
Reviews.Content: Good location, clean, and the owners of both the Dulcinea and Pension Corbero over the road were very friendly and helpful. You even got a strange little safebox in the room for valuables. We would stay here again without hesitation. From memory, the Corbero was a little cheaper but only by a few euros.

Reviews.Title: “great location & price”
Reviews.Author: kimxtom
Reviews.Content: Hostal Dulcinea is in a great location - near several metro stops and walking distance to Prado museum, Atocha railway station and many restaurants. The room was small, but not cramped and included A/C. It was quiet, well-kept and inexpensive. We would definitely go back!

Reviews.Title: “Spotless and ideal location”
Reviews.Author: Gillz79
Reviews.Content: Booked this hostal based on the location as visiting friends in Madrid and wanted to be close to metro and nightlife, couldn't have picked a better location. I'm baffled by the reviews stating the owner was rude, we found them friendly and welcoming and although they didn't speak English we managed to communicate with them in my little Spanish and a lot of hand signals. The sheets and towels were changed each day and room and bathroom kept spotless. There was a safety deposit box in the room and main doors locked at night so felt secure and safe. The walls are thin as we could hear next door room getting up and having a shower and the owners cleaning in the morning in the corridor. The hostal is in a residential building so we could hear the child upstairs running about but living in a flat in the UK this didn't bother us. All in all Dulcinea is a good location, spotlessly clean, friendly and helpful staff and at £20 per night excellant value.

Reviews.Title: “Rude manager”
Reviews.Author: maura_sbrown
Reviews.Content: The rooms were small but clean. The guy who was in charge was very rude and nosy. He was always watching us as we came and went out. He "yelled" at my adult children when they spoke in the halls. The location is good but with all options in the area would not stay again or recommend it to others.

Reviews.Title: “Noisy at night, rude and nosy guy”
Reviews.Author: LorenaMP
Reviews.Content: The place is has an excellent location. The rooms are tiny and clean but the guy who was at the desk was nosy and rude. The first nights went well but our last night there someone decided to rearrange furniture - the floor above. We could not sleep, it was bad.

Reviews.Title: “Completely average hostal. Slightly overpriced.”
Reviews.Author: Sheenayparaguas
Reviews.Content: It was utterly average. Good sized room, bed, bathroom, lock box. You can leave your bags for a while on checkout day. Very good location once you get your bearings. (We had some trouble finding it.) Quick walk to Prado, Retiro, Plazas to the west, and metro stations. It is very far from the airport, but for 2 euros I can't complain. One of the 2 owners/managers was friendly and the other...wasn't. The walls are a bit thin but any noise was only noticeable during the day. There is no breakfast or internet, but both are available in nearby shops. Overall it is a great place to start out in. Good for getting familiar with the attractions and getting over your jet lag.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, clean!”
Reviews.Author: Kristin862
Reviews.Content: The hostal is in a great location and is clean and the owners are really nice but no little English, so make sure to brush up on your English in advance, it helps! The only complaint is that he "shhh" my friend and I one night at 11:30 PM which was kind of creepy especially since we weren't being that loud but other than that it was a great place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Great location,wonderful hosts. Best place to stay for the museums”
Reviews.Author: jel7374
Reviews.Content: Close to the Prado and the 2 other top museums in Madrid. 2 blocks from all the top hotels. The owners are very nice. Would stay there again, definitely. Very safe, good security. Building has lots of character.

Reviews.Title: “Very Clean, thin walls!!!”
Reviews.Author: purpleLili
Reviews.Content: Hostal Dulcinea was quite an adventure. As you arrive you will notice construction going on and a very old creaky building that you must enter to get into the hostal. However as you take the elevator to the 3rd floor you begin to understand tha value of this hostal. The hostal is well situated on a very quiet street equally distanced from Plaza Mayor and the Prado museum. The rooms are VERY clean, and everything in our room was in good condition. The room is small and my husbands feet dangled a little of the bed, but for the price this is a great hostal, where you will not have to worry about bed bugs!!!! Our room had a nice little balcony and a "cozy" full bathroom. If you are on a budget this is a great choice, but the Ritz it is not!!!

Reviews.Title: “It was Good and clean”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Getting there from the airport was a nightmare on the metro as you have to change trains three times just to get to Anton Martin and even then there is a 5 min walk. We were a bit suprised by the entrance of the hostal as it looked very old fashioned with wooden staircases and a old school looking lift which was quite good fun.The room was clean and nice with a TV AND A FAN!!!! EVEN A BATH!!! we had a twin private room tho with a private bath. There was a fresh made bed and towels every morning which was nice. The walls where a little bit thin as we got shhhhhhd twice! Its location is very good as you are in walking distance of Puerta Del Sol and Retiro Parque. Also very close to the congresso which is like Parliment in England and Congress in America. We also recomd the fruit smoothie shop on the way to the Puerta Del Sol just after the Congresso. The owners were vrery nice and welcoming and seemed to recognise everyone that was staying. we would definately recommend this to couples or anyone lookin for a cheap place to stay when in Madrid.

Reviews.Title: “Oh, to be Younger!”
Reviews.Author: JoelleA
Reviews.Content: We stayed 5 nights the Hostal Dulcinea and it is a very convenient base for seeing the city as well as taking trips out of town, just a short walk to the Antocha train station and Avis. We took the train to Seville from there and picked up the rental car the same spot for a day trip to Segovia. It's an easy walk to the Puerto del Sol area, and all the monuments, plus convenient, interlocking metro lines, which we took to a bullfight (left after two events). You can fall out of your bed into The Prado which had the best recorded tour guide ever! And the Hard Rock Cafe is another fifteen minutes up the Passeo, if a thick burger and steak is to your liking. The owners Jose and Maria were very nice and went out of their way to help us, moving our room to an interior one at our request and also, on our return via the shuttle (fast and inexpensive). The room was exactly as advertised, clean, fresh, always made up. It was very economical, but it would have been better for us had we done this 30 years ago. By the way, its house number is typical of many locattions. We walked the length of Cervantes and couldn't find it, needing the help of 2 local residents. Number 19 is right opposite thirty-something! If you're young and sleepless in Madrid, you're sure to enjoy it here.

Reviews.Title: “Clean and affordable”
Reviews.Author: markmark
Reviews.Content: Basic pension in central Madrid. We paid 48 euros/night for a double with bathroom - no breakfast. Room was clean but very basic. Owners speak very little English but are very nice. Location is very good for most attractions.

Reviews.Title: “Simple but nice”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed 2 nights the hotel Dulcinea in the end of May 2004, we had booked the room 2 months in advance using recommendations from this site. The owners Jose and Maria were very nice, the fact that we spoke spanish made our conversations very easy during our stay. They had also given us good recommendations for getting from the airport to the hotel previous to our arrival.(a taxi should cost between 13-20 euros depending on your luggage) A small elevator takes you to the 3rd floor of this simple but cozy Hostal. There is a fair amount of morning noise on the street side of the hotel but not all rooms are on this side. Our room was a bit small but very clean and more than adequate for 2 people, with a full size bed and a bonus twin size also. We had a TV, small desk, night stand and nice sized closet. We had a complete bathroom with a small tub, shower, sink, toilet and bidet. The water pressure is good and stayed hot. The location is excellent, a 5 minute walk to the Prado, Metro Station and around the corner from a Starbucks (of course) . This hostel was the best deal on our whole trip(of 6 cities) We had a nice visit and would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Clean, but thin walls”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hostal is cheap enough by Madrid standards, and pretty clean, but the walls are quite thin -- conversations next door could be easily heard. So easy that it was possible to hear somebody "shhushing" us when we were talking a little too loud one night.

HotelInfo.Name: Hostal Dulcinea
HotelInfo.Address: Cervantes 19, 28014 Madrid, Spain
